VI. MISCELLANEOUS GRANTS
Travel-study Grant for the NAEB Executive Director
In 1953, when Dr, Harry Skornia was employed as NAEB Execu¬
tive Director, a small grant of $956 was received from the FAE to permit
him to visit the ETV stations and many of the NAEB member radio stations.
Having been out of the country for much of the preceding five years, a
reorientation and personal contact visitation was felt desirable before he
settled into the routine of the position.
This grant was important in two respects. It permitted the Execu¬
tive Director to gain first-hand knowledge about the operation and needs
of stations throughout the country, and it enabled staff members of sta¬
tions to learn more about the services provided by the NAEB and to express
their opinions about the kinds of services that should be made available
in the future.
Because of these visits a closer liaison was established between
NAEB Headquarters and educational stations. The Executive Director
was more sensitive to the needs of the stations than he could otherwise
have been. This led to the institution of new services and continuation
of on-going services which could be most helpful to the stations and their
staffs. Educational broadcasters, who often have to work in a ''vacuum"
without adequate contact with other educational broadcasters, came to
realize that someone was interested in their problems and willing to help
in every way possible. In addition, the Executive Director was able to
